perturbation.explanation: The contract originally states that New York law governs the agreement, but this is changed to Delaware law, and is placed after a clause describing Stock Purchase Contract Agent rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Obligations Law ยง 5-1401
perturbation.law_explanation: NY GOL ยง 5-1401 allows parties to a contract of $250,000 or more to stipulate that New York law will govern, regardless of conflict of laws principles. By changing the governing law to Delaware *after* the clause regarding Stock Purchase Contract Agent rights, and if the conditions in NY GOL 5-1401 are met, the relocation could create ambiguity and potential unenforceability of the original New York law clause because the Stock Purchase Contract Agent right clause seems to take precedent, and because a Delaware court is unlikely to enforce NY GOL 5-1401.

perturbation.changed_text:
(a) The Company will indemnify and hold harmless each Remarketing Agent, its partners, directors and officers and each person, if any, who controls such Remarketing Agent within the meaning of either Section 15 of the Act or Section 20 of the Exchange Act, against any losses, claims, damages or liabilities, joint or several, to which such Remarketing Agent may become subject, under the Act or otherwise, insofar as such losses, claims, damages or liabilities (or actions in respect thereof) arise out of or are based upon an untrue statement or alleged untrue statement of a material fact contained in (i) the Registration Statement or any amendment or supplement (when considered together with the document to which such supplement relates) thereto, or arise out of or are based upon the omission or alleged omission to state therein a material fact required to be stated therein or necessary to make the statements therein not misleading or (ii) any Preliminary Prospectus, Pricing Prospectus, any Issuer Free Writing Prospectus or the Final Prospectus or any amendment or supplement (when considered together with the document to which such supplement relates) thereto, or any "issuer information" filed or required to be filed pursuant to Rule 433(d) under the Act, or arise out of or are based upon the omission or alleged omission to state therein a material fact required to be stated therein or necessary to make the statements therein, in light of the circumstances under which they were made, not misleading, and will reimburse each Remarketing Agent for any legal or other expenses reasonably incurred by such Remarketing Agent in connection with investigating or defending any such action or claim as such expenses are incurred; provided, however, that the Company shall not be liable in any such case to the extent that any such loss, claim, damage or liability (or action in respect thereof) arises out of or is based upon an untrue statement or alleged untrue statement or omission or alleged omission made in any Preliminary Prospectus, any Issuer Free Writing Prospectus, Pricing Prospectus, the Registration Statement or the
Final Prospectus, or any such amendment or supplement(s) even when the Remarketing Agent does *not* provide information to the Company for use therein.
perturbation.explanation: The change removes the condition that relies on written information furnished by the Remarketing Agent, so even if the misstatement arises from information *not* furnished by the Remarketing Agent, the Company is still liable. This could be considered an illegal condition, since the liability is unfairly broadened.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 11 of the Securities Act of 1933 imposes liability on issuers and others for material misstatements or omissions in a registration statement. However, it also provides a 'due diligence' defense, where parties can avoid liability by demonstrating they conducted a reasonable investigation and had reasonable grounds to believe the statements were true and not misleading. By removing the condition, the indemnification clause shifts the entire burden of liability to the company, even in cases where the Remarketing Agent failed to conduct proper due diligence, thus undermining the purpose and protections afforded by Section 11. The company would essentially indemnify the underwriter even for its own negligence, which is against the spirit and intent of securities laws.

perturbation.explanation: The jury trial waiver is moved to be nested within the Appointment and Obligations section, specifically buried in the first paragraph. This makes it much less conspicuous than when it has its own section at the end.
perturbation.law_explanation: While jury trial waivers are generally enforceable, they must be knowing and voluntary. Relocating the waiver to an unexpected section like 'Appointment and Obligations,' especially burying it within a paragraph detailing agent duties, obscures its significance. This diminishes the likelihood that the waiver was entered into knowingly and voluntarily, thus creating an argument that it violates the spirit, if not the letter, of the 7th Amendment right to a jury trial.
